title: How to Say I Love You in German

steps.title: Say "I love you" by saying "Ich liebe dich."
steps.content: Say "I love you" by saying "Ich liebe dich." [1] X Research source We'll show you how to pronounce each single word, but phonetically it sounds something like this: [ɪç 'li:bə dɪç].

steps.title: Say "ich."
steps.content: Say "ich." This is the "I" in "I love you. " The /ch/ sound in "ich," which is also called a voiceless palatal fricative, isn't pronounced the same way you would pronounce it in English. [2] X Research source It sounds something like the /j/ sound in Spanish, kind of like a snake hissing. The /ch/ sound is really hard for non-native speakers to master. Most English-speakers getting away with saying "ish," as in "finish" or "fish."

steps.title: Say "liebe."
steps.content: Say "liebe." This is the "love" in "I love you." Say this slowly "lee-buh." [3] X Research source The "l" is pronounced normally but the "ie" is pronounced as "ee" like in "tree" and "bee." The "be" at the end of it is pronounced like the "b" in "burn." Put it together to form "liebe."

steps.title: Say "dich."
steps.content: Say "dich." The "ich" in "dich" is pronounced the same as "ich" in the first step. [4] X Research source "Dich" sounds similar to the English word "dish," except the /ch/ sound is produced in the middle of the mouth instead of the front. [5] X Research source This is the "you" in "I love you".

steps.title: Say "I have fallen in love with you.
steps.content: Say "I have fallen in love with you. " A different, albeit more formal, way of saying "I love you," this wording is very romantic. Here's how you say it: "Ich habe mich in dich verliebt." [6] X Research source The phonetic pronunciation is [ɪç 'ha:bə mɪç ɪn dɪç fɛɐ'li:pt].

steps.title: Say "I like you a lot.
steps.content: Say "I like you a lot. " To say this: "Ich mag dich sehr," which literally translates to "I like you very" (although a bit smoother in German). [7] X Research source The phonetic pronunciation here is [ɪç ma:k dɪç ze:ɐ].

steps.title: Say "I like you.
steps.content: Say "I like you. " To say this: "Du gefällst mir." [8] X Research source The phonetic pronunciation here is [du: gə'fɛlst mi:ə].

steps.title: Add terms of endearment to your compliments.
steps.content: Add terms of endearment to your compliments. If you really want your compliments to leave a mark, be sure to add a term of endearment to your "I love you's." Here are two specifically that you can use: "Schatz," meaning "sweetheart" but literally "treasure." [9] X Research source Phonetically, it's pronounced [ʃats]. Try "Mein Schatz, ich liebe dich!" or "Ich liebe dich, Schatzi." "Liebling," meaning "darling." Phonetically, it's pronounced ['li:plɪŋ]. Try "Liebling, du bist so hübsch." ("Darling, you are so pretty.")
